introduction: A fundamental topic in engineering mechanics, engineering dynamics examines how bodies move in response to forces and moments. By offering real-world and virtual experiments on subjects like moment of inertia, rolling motion, energy and momentum conservation, rotational motion, vibration, and motion under gravitational and resistive forces, the Engineering Dynamics Laboratory aims to enhance theoretical understanding of dynamics. These experiments help students bridge the gap between classroom theory and practical engineering applications by allowing them to visualize dynamic behavior, validate basic laws, and hone their analytical and problem-solving abilities.

experiments.name: To determine the moment of Inertia of a Flywheel
To determine mass moment of inertia of a pendulum (ordinary, compound)
To study rolling motion on horizontal/inclined plane (multiple objects of different MI with and without slipping)
To determine the gravitational acceleration, terminal speed and drag force
To validate the conservation of total mechanical energy and energy transformation
To measure the coefficient of restitution and validate the conservation of momentum (collision of elastic bodies)
To investigate the relationship between torque and angular acceleration and to verify the work-energy theorem for rotational motion
To validate the conservation of angular momentum (Gyroscope)
To find out the coriolis component of acceleration
To study the free vibration of SDOF mass-spring system

objective:
• To enable the students to understand and appreciate the basic principles of Engineering Mechanics
  • To provide a virtual environment for students for self-learning
